data.description: Explore a rugged, isolated island far from our connected communities. Isle Royale offers adventures for backpackers, hikers, boaters, paddlers, and divers. Cross Lake Superior and make a commitment: Become a part of this island, and let it become a part of you. Find peace and refuge in island wilderness – because Isle Royale, in turn, finds refuge in us. Help Isle Royale stay wild.

entranceFees.description:
$7 per person per day to enter or remain in Isle Royale National Park. Children 15 and younger are exempt.

Visiting Park Headquarters in Houghton, MI does not require a fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Isle Royale Season Pass: $60 valid from April 16 through October 31 of the year indicated. Pass covers fees for the pass holder and up to three adults traveling with the pass holder (four total).
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Isle Royale National Park headquarters is located in Houghton, MI. Visit the Houghton page on the Isle Royale National Park website for additional information and a map on how to access the visitor center.

operatingHours.description: Isle Royale National Park is open annually from April 16 to October 31. Transportation services are offered from May to September. The island and its surrounding islands are closed to all visitors from November 1 to April 15 due to extreme winter weather conditions and for the safety and protection of visitors. This closure extends 4.5 miles out into Lake Superior from the island. Park headquarters during the winter is in Houghton, Michigan. Summer headquarters is located at Mott Island on Isle Royale.
operatingHours.name: Isle Royale National Park Open Season (April 16 through October 31)

images.title: Duncan Bay Narrows
images.altText: View from above the trees looking down at Duncan Bay Narrows, trees, Lake Superior, and Canada.
images.caption: Isle Royale, located in the northwestern corner of Lake Superior, offers views of the Canadian shoreline.

images.title: Winter Ice Floes
images.altText: Ice floes float in a harbor
images.caption: Isle Royale National Park is closed in winter, with the exception of a few visiting researchers.

images.title: Aerial View of Belle Harbor
images.altText: Aerial View of Belle Harbor
images.caption: Isle Royale is also called Minong, which means "the good place" by the Grand Portage Band of Lake Superior Chippewa. Minong is a part of the ancestral lands of the Anishinaabe/Ojibwe peoples who have cared for these lands from time immemorial.

images.title: Bull Moose
images.altText: Young bull moose browsing for food
images.caption: Moose are one of the few mammal species who have journeyed to the island.

images.title: Rock of Ages Lighthouse
images.altText: Aerial view of Rock of Ages Lighthouse
images.caption: Rock of Ages is one of four lighthouses at Isle Royale National Park.

images.title: Aurora Borealis Over Isle Royale National Park
images.altText: Diverse colored Aurora Borealis in the night sky
images.caption: Isle Royale National Park's dark skies make it an excellent location to enjoy nighttime phenomenon, like the Aurora Borealis.

data.weatherInfo: Isle Royale National Park is a remote island wilderness in the middle of Lake Superior. Weather influences traveling to and from the island, as well as your trip once you arrive. For the most up-to-date weather information, call (906) 482-0984 or email isro_parkinfo@nps.gov prior to your trip.
data.name: Isle Royale

data.description: The stories of people and copper in the Keweenaw Peninsula have been intertwined for more than 7,000 years. Indigenous peoples made copper into tools and trade items. Investors and immigrants arrived in the 1800s in a great mineral rush, developing thriving industries and cosmopolitan communities. Though the mines have since closed, their mark is still visible on the land and people.
data.directionsInfo: Keweenaw National Historical Park is located is located on the Keweenaw Peninsula, the northernmost part of Upper Michigan.

operatingHours.description: The Calumet Unit of Keweenaw NHP encompasses the Village of Calumet and part of Calumet Township. Park grounds (with the exception of private property and the Keweenaw Heritage Sites) are open to the public from sunrise to sunset. The Calumet Visitor Center at 98 Fifth Street has seasonal hours of operation.
operatingHours.name: Calumet Unit

operatingHours.description: The Quincy Unit of Keweenaw NHP encompasses Quincy Mine Hoist Association property and the Quincy Smelting Works. Both the Quincy Mine Hoist Association property and the Quincy Smelting Works are owned and operated by not-for-profit entities. Park grounds (with the exception of private property) are open to the public from sunrise to sunset.
operatingHours.name: Quincy Unit

images.title: Keweenaw NHP Headquarters
images.altText: Two story stone and brick building. The American flag flies in front of a blue sky background
images.caption: Park Headquarters is housed in the former Calumet & Hecla Mining Company General Office building.

images.title: Keweenaw History Center
images.altText: Two story stone and brick building. a ranger leads a group of visitors in front or the steps
images.caption: A ranger guided walk outside the former Calumet & Hecla Public Library, now known at the Keweenaw History Center.

images.title: Calumet Visitor Center
images.altText: Three story brick building, with snow covered trees along the right side
images.caption: The Calumet Visitor Center in the historic Union Building showcases three floors of interactive exhibits, films, and museum pieces.

images.title: Quincy Mine
images.altText: 140 foot tall industrial building with a steeply pitched roofline under blue skies and snowy ground
images.caption: The Quincy Mining Company #2 Shaft-Rockhouse and Hoist House in winter.

images.title: Quincy Mining Company Smelter
images.altText: With a colorful autumn background, numerous industrial buildings sit on the waterfront
images.caption: The Quincy Smelter is one of the best-preserved copper smelting facilities of its era.

data.weatherInfo: Summer: Keweenaw summers are usually mild, with average highs in the 70s, but can reach into the 80s and 90s. Nighttime temperatures are typically cool, but can also dip into the 40s or stay in the 70s. Summer months are dry, with occasional rain or severe thunderstorms. Winter: Again influenced by Lake Superior, winter temperatures are mild with highs in the 20s. Cold spells can occur with subzero temperatures. Lake effect snow is common, and 300 inches of snow can fall in a season.
data.name: Keweenaw

data.description: Come to the North Country. Trek the hills and valleys. Stand on the shores of lakes & streams from glaciers 10,000 years before. Clear-flowing water, red/gold of autumn, a fairyland of snow, open prairies, and distant horizons paint the land. Historic sites along the way tell how America settled and grew as a nation. From North Dakota to Vermont, adventure is never far away.
data.directionsInfo: There are numerous trailheads to access the trail. Find North Country Trail Association's Maps and Trails Data to help you get there at https://northcountrytrail.org/trail/maps.

operatingHours.description: The North Country Trail is generally open at all times and during all seasons. There may be area or seasonal closures at the discretion of the local land owner or manager. Please contact local managers or the North Country Trail Association at (616) 897-5987 x1 for the latest trail closures.
operatingHours.name: Trail Hours

images.title: Hiking the North Country Trail
images.altText: Hiking on trail
images.caption: The trail links scenic, natural, historic, and cultural areas across seven states allowing visitors to experience a variety of northern landscapes.

images.title: Fall foliage
images.altText: Fall colors along the trail
images.caption: Enjoy the seasonal changes along the North Country Trail

images.title: Hiking the NCT
images.altText: Hiking on the North Country Trail
images.caption: A variety of landscapes are present along the North Country Trail.

images.title: Trail sign
images.altText: North Country trail sign
images.caption: Trail sign

images.title: North Country National Scenic Trail Trailhead
images.altText: Bulletin board at a trailhead in a forest that features a map and brochures.
images.caption: North Country National Scenic Trail Trailhead in the Chippewa National Forest, Minnesota.

data.weatherInfo: With the trail going through more than 4,800 miles through eight states from the Northeast to the Great Plains, weather along the trail can be highly variable. You could be subject to any kind of weather or temperature related emergency depending on your location and the season. Be careful to protect yourself from heat-related illnesses and hypothermia while out on the trail. Be mindful of lightning, severe storms, and other environmental hazards common to the “North Country.”
data.name: North Country

data.description: Sandstone cliffs, beaches, waterfalls, sand dunes, inland lakes, deep forest, and wild shoreline beckon you to visit Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore. The power of Lake Superior shapes the park's coastal features and affects every ecosystem, creating a unique landscape to explore. Hiking, camping, sightseeing, and four-season outdoor opportunities abound.

entranceFees.description: This pass admits the driver and all passengers in a private-use vehicle for seven consecutive days to all areas of Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore. This fee does not cover additional fees associated with activities such as camping or commercial tours.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: This pass admits a motorcyclist and passenger (if applicable) to all areas of Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore for 7 consecutive days. This fee does not cover additional fees associated with activities such as camping or commercial tours.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: This pass admits a snowmobile to all parts of Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore for 7 consecutive days. This fee does not cover additional fees associated with activities such as camping or commercial tours.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Snowmobile

entranceFees.description: This pass admits one walk-in, bicycle-in, or boat-in person to all parts of Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore. This fee does not cover additional fees associated with activities such as camping or commercial tours.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: This admits a commercial sedan to all areas of Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore. The flat rate for this pass is $25, plus an additional $5 per person age 16+. This fee does not cover additional fees associated with activities such as camping or commercial tours.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description: This pass admits a commercial van with a capacity of 7-16 persons, regardless of capacity, to all parts of Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore. This fee does not cover additional fees associated with activities such as camping or commercial tours.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: This fee admits a commercial mini-bus to all parts of Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore. A mini-bus is defined as a vehicle with a 16-25 person capacity. The fee is charged regardless of occupancy of the vehicle. This fee does not cover additional fees associated with activities such as camping or commercial tours.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: This fee applies to commercial vehicles with a 26+ person vehicle capacity, regardless of occupancy. This fee does not cover additional fees associated with activities such as camping or commercial tours.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entrancePasses.description: This annual pass is specific to Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore. It admits a driver and passengers in a private vehicle, or the cardholder plus three additional people to the park for 12 months from the purchase month. This pass does not cover other fees associated with activities such as camping or commercial tours.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Pictured Rocks NL is located on the south shore of Lake Superior in Michigan's Upper Peninsula, between the towns of Munising (west) and Grand Marais (east). Access the west side of the park via Michigan highways M-28 and M-94 to Munising. State highway M-77 leads to Grand Marais on the east side. Alger County Road H-58 runs parallel and through the park, providing access to spur roads that lead to scenic overlooks, trailheads, campgrounds, beaches, etc. Most park roads are closed in winter due to snow.

operatingHours.description: Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore is open year-round, 24 hours a day, though most roads are closed by snow in the winter. Sand Point Road is the only park road plowed in winter.
operatingHours.name: Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore

images.altText: Mineral stained cliffs and collapsed rock arch along Lake Superior
images.caption: Springtime along the Chapel / Mosquito hiking loop

data.weatherInfo: Summers are pleasant with the average highs in June, July, and August in the 70s°F, and lows in the low 50s°F. The coldest months are December through March with average highs of 25°F to 32°F, and average lows in the teens. Annual precipitation averages 31 inches; average annual snowfall is about 140 inches, although winters with more than 200 inches are not uncommon. Snow generally covers the ground from late November through late April.
data.name: Pictured Rocks

data.description: River Raisin NBP preserves, commemorates, and interprets the January 1813 battles of the War of 1812 and their aftermath. Battles that resulted in the greatest victory for Tecumseh’s Confederation and the British and the greatest defeat for the U.S. The aftermath led to U.S. Indian laws that forced the removal, relocation, and assimilation of native nations, an aftermath that continues today.
data.directionsInfo: River Raisin National Battlefield is located in SE Lower Michigan along the western shoreline of Lake Erie, in the city of Monroe. Park headquarters is 35 miles south of Detroit, and only 270 miles east of Chicago. By Car: Take Interstate 75 to exit 15 and go south on Dixie Highway to 333 North Dixie Hwy on the right.

operatingHours.description: The visitor center contains a 24-foot diorama of the River Raisin Settlement, maps, ranger programs, basic park orientation, park store, passport stamp and Park film. We are open year-round. Please check seasonal hours for times of operation. We are closed on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day.
operatingHours.name: River Raisin National Battlefield Park

images.title: Battle of the River Raisin
images.altText: Painting of the Battle of the River Raisin
images.caption: The January 22, 1813 Battle raging in the snowy village of Frenchtown

images.title: Remember the Raisin!
images.altText: re-enactors firing in a battle line
images.caption: Annual Commemoration of the Battle in January

images.title: British Sled Cannon
images.altText: a sled cannon in the snow
images.caption: British ingenuity - adopting their cannons for the snowy conditions at the Battle

images.title: Summer in the Park
images.altText: period gardens
images.caption: Visitors enjoy the period gardens and trails in the Park

images.title: River Raisin National Battlefield Park
images.altText: Grounds and structure
images.caption: River Raisin National Battlefield Park

images.title: River Raisin National Battlefield Park
images.altText: Grounds and structure
images.caption: River Raisin National Battlefield Park

data.weatherInfo: There is a saying about Michigan weather: "If you don't like the weather wait five minutes and it will change!" Seasonal average temperatures for Monroe area: Winter: highs range from 30 F- 45 F and lows range from 15 F- 30 F Spring: highs range from 40 F - 70 F and lows range from 25 F - 55 F Summer: highs range from 70 F - 85 F and lows range from 50 F - 65 F Fall: highs range from 40 F - 80 F and lows range from 60 F - 30 F
data.name: River Raisin

data.description: Miles of sand beach, bluffs that tower 450’ above Lake Michigan, lush forests, clear inland lakes, unique flora and fauna make up the natural world of Sleeping Bear Dunes. High dunes afford spectacular views across the lake. An island lighthouse, US Life-Saving Service stations, coastal villages, and picturesque farmsteads reflect the park’s rich maritime, agricultural, and recreational history.

entranceFees.description:
Sedan
1-6 Person Capacity
$25.00 + $10.00 Per Person 16 years or older (up to a maximum of $40.00)
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

data.directionsInfo: From the south (Detroit or Chicago areas) :Take US-31, US-131, US-27 to M-115 & M-37, I-75 and M-72 North to Traverse City, then west on M-72 to the Village of Empire. You will see the visitor center as you enter Empire on your right. You may also get to Empire from the south via US-31 to Ludington and then north to Manistee. You can follow either US-31 or M-22 from north of Manistee. From the north (Michigan's Upper Peninsula), take I-75 to Grayling and follow M-72 to Traverse City or take US-31 south

operatingHours.description: The Lakeshore is open 24 hours a day. Campgrounds, visitor centers, and facilities have separate hours, however, please see descriptions of those facilities elsewhere.
operatingHours.name: Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore

data.weatherInfo: Spring: Temperatures usually range from 40 F to 70 F. Rain is common. Summer: Temperatures usually range from from 50 F to 83 F. Rain and sun are equally common. On very sunny days, be prepared with plenty of water--heat exhaustion is common, especially when hiking on the dunes. Fall: Temperatures range from 40 F to 70 F. Fall foliage is at its peak around mid September. Winter: Temperatures range from 15 F to 40 F. Snow is common and is on the ground for most of the winter. Dress in warm layers.
data.name: Sleeping Bear Dunes
